abstract.p: Nancy Yanes Hoffman letter on Joel Brinkley's Sept 21 article lauds WordPerfect software

block.p: Bravo to Joel Brinkley for singing the praises of WordPerfect (''It's a Word World, or Is It?'' Sept 21). Not only is WordPerfect's Reveal Codes function a real convenience, and not only is its price far lower than Microsoft Word's, but it is easier to use, requires fewer keystrokes and is less insistent on having its own way with the unwelcome insertion of extra numbers or letters in a list. That law offices and the Justice Department use Word Perfect is one of the best things I've heard about the legal profession.

Bravo to Joel Brinkley for singing the praises of WordPerfect (''It's a Word World, or Is It?'' Sept 21). Not only is WordPerfect's Reveal Codes function a real convenience, and not only is its price far lower than Microsoft Word's, but it is easier to use, requires fewer keystrokes and is less insistent on having its own way with the unwelcome insertion of extra numbers or letters in a list. That law offices and the Justice Department use Word Perfect is one of the best things I've heard about the legal profession.

But there is one problem with WordPerfect: While I can convert WordPerfect 6, 7, 8 and 9 to Word, I cannot convert Word to WordPerfect. It will work one way, but it absolutely won't convert a Word document to WordPerfect. Word is sneaky about not permitting you to use another system. Corel, it's time to get off the stick and do some plain and fancy advertising and public relations about the virtues of Word Perfect to break Word's hammerlock on PC's.
